ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about all four case studies upon which we focused as well as some very helpful lessons for approaching foreign policy altogether. This was one of the best classes I've taken at Yale. I was highly engaged and looked forward to every week's insightful discussions.

This course developed my ability to view both sides of conflicts/tensions, and use this perspective to understand the actions of each side. Importantly, even in situations where I had a clear prior opinion, I was still able to look from the other side's point of view with more patience, nuance and understanding than I had previously. 

Helped me think about how I would approach difficult foreign policy decisions in the future - in particular, how previous / recent events and domestic politics might bias me towards a direction for a different situation, and how important it is to take into account the context of every situation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the reading list, engagement of the students, class discussions, how often Professor Malley pushed students to justify their logic and how engaged he was with our discussions.

Weaknesses: not a weakness, per se, but I loved when Professor Malley lectured at the start of class and think the course would be improved if he leaned into that a bit more. Our discussions were great, but I liked it when he spent time at the start framing them.
Amazing professor, really interesting discussion! Loved that Prof. Malley considered student input while shaping the class.

Strengths: 
- Excellent structured discussions 
- Passionate and engaged lecturer 
- Thoughtful and diverse group of students  
- Respectful discussions even when speaking about emotive topics 

Weaknesses 
- instructor could focus a little more on who he chooses to speak and the frequency with which they have already spoken to ensure widespread representation of speakers
Great class, great instructor! Sometimes class would run overtime and I think that that should be improved but no other weaknesses!
Great readings, liked the focus on the chosen scenarios, sometimes I wish course stayed closer to the theme, but I learned a lot from free flowing discussions too.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. It is rare students get opportunities to study with actual decision makers who have been "in the room where it happens." I learned an incredibly amount in this class. The reading list was excellent and the class discussions were very well-informed.

Absolutely! Professor Malley is an incredible addition to the Jackson School. This was one of the most interesting classes I've taken at Yale because it spurred difficult but respectful conversations. I learned so much from the professor and my fellow classmates!

Yes, the combination of an engaged and experienced lecturer, carefully selected reading list and focus on cognitive empathy made this class really enjoyable and an excellent learning experience for those interested in global affairs.
100% if they're interested in the American diplomacy concerning the region
Absolutely. Great discussion and you learn from your classmates a ton.

extras.title: GLBL 323 01 - Int'l Politics of Middle East
